Sarra Chaieb
Intergenerational transmission of trajectories
of suffering in precarious environments
Researching the younger generations’ strategies of
reinterpretation
Abstract:
This article discusses some pivotal questions regarding processes of the intergenerational
transmission of trajectories of suffering in precarious places: to what extent can such pro-
cesses provide resources that foster agency
column2: and to what extent do they rather constitute

column1: barriers to living one’s own life? How much do intergenerational relations allow for cer-
tain reinterpretations while discouraging or inhibiting others? Which reinterpretations of
the older generations’ experiences appear legitimate in certain contexts
rebuked by one’s social environment?
In order to pursue these questions we present analyses of two very different cases that
are based on two forms of data material – the life story of Emma
and ethno-analytic group interviews with adolescents aged 14 to 20. Both cases are em-
bedded in very different regional and political contexts: the former
of fostering institutions
column2: and the latter a Palestinian refugee camp in the West Bank.

column1: Both constitute
column3: cases of intergenerational transmission of trajectories of suffer-

column1: ing. One objective of this article is to illustrate how the contrasting of such cases across
different kinds of data and contexts can be heuristically useful for methodologically gaug-
ing the spectrum of the ubiquitous and sometimes paradoxical phenomena of intergenera-
tional transmission
column2: in order to further develop its conceptualization.

column1: Key words: intergenerational transmission
ations

Intergenerational transmission is a ubiquitous phenomenon that has been dis-
cussed across disciplines such as psychoanalysis
and education. It comes into play when we debate questions of the very reproduc-
tion of society

The following analysis of two case studies (in part II.) will reveal some unex-
pected dynamics regarding the questions outlined above. We present two cases of
intergenerational transmission of trajectories of suffering – or trauma1 – in what
can be called precarious environments
column2: albeit in very different contexts: the

column1: French system of fostering institutions and a refugee camp in the West Bank. In
both cases
column2: the previous generation had migrated before our interviewees were

column1: born; but in the first case
column2: the migration of the older generation is contextualized

column1: by French migration policies and the country’s economic need for labor power
while in the case situated in Palestine
column2: the older generation fled out of fear of po-

column1: litical violence or was in fact expelled. We are aware that both cases differ in more
than in this aspect: the data material consists in the first case of an individual bi-
ographical interview
column2: in the second case of consecutive group interviews. More-

column1: over
column2: the interviewees are of a very different age at the time of the interview: in

column1: the first case it is a woman of 58 years who by now is a mother herself; in the sec-
ond case they are young people aged 14 to 21.
Given that our cases differ in a variety of aspects
column2: our idea is not to compare

column1: our two cases in the strict sense
column2: but rather to discuss them in their similarities

column1: and differences regarding processes of intergenerational transmission. This point
of view allows us to understand the “how” rather than the “why” (Becker 1998)
and to gain an understanding of the processes that are in the background of our
two cases of intergenerational transmission in a precarious environment.
Furthermore
column2: discussing these two cases side by side was at first merely helpful

column1: for finding out more about each respective individual case. But we soon realized
that both cases have more in common than one would suspect at first sight by as-
sessing their external criteria.
In the ensuing discussion (3) we will reflect upon the common structural dy-
namics and differences of both cases. However
column2: we are aware that this discussion

column1: is testing the limits of casing and comparing. Therefore
will reflect upon the results but also upon more general questions of “comparabil-
ity” and casing
column2: and the pitfalls and opportunities that comparisons of such differ-

column1: ent cases imply.

2.1 Case Study 1: Growing up in French child welfare.
By interviewing adults who were fostered during their childhood and adolescence
Sarra Chaïeb’s research tries to understand how members of ethnic or religious
minority groups experienced their placement in two child protection organizations
that are historically characterized by religion (Judaism and Catholicism). On the
one hand
column2: she asks how the two care institutions impact people’s life courses and

column1: their sense of belonging
column2: in regard to the socialization in their families. On the

column1: other hand

exploratory phase of this research

column1: also emerged throughout the subsequent interviews: the sense of belonging
construction of socialization between the institution and the family and the con-
tradictions this can cause

2.1.1 Emma: Elements of her life course
Emma is a 58-year-old woman. She is married and lives with her husband in their
house near Paris. They have three children who are between 20 and 30 years old.
She has been a nurse since the age of 27.
Emma was fostered again and again during her youth
ods when her mother gave birth to Emma’s brothers and sisters. Emma is the eld-
est of a family of eleven children
column2: and was born in Tunisia when the country was

column1: still a French protectorate. Her mother is Kabyle Algerian. Her father
fought for France during the Second World War

This case illustrates the concept of transmission and allows us to think of this no-
tion as a dynamic one. As a case of an “extreme situation” of transmission (Ber-
taux 1997)
column2: it can challenge the notion and point to some new dimensions. We can

column1: see that Emma finds a dimension of transmission from her mother in her life
course in spite of how her mother acted towards her. Taking an active part in re-
interpretation seems to be very important in the case of transmission in this pre-
carious environment.
2.2 Case Study 2: Growing up in a Palestinian refugee camp
This second case study is based on Christoph H. Schwarz’ (2014) research on the
structure of potential spaces of adolescence (King 2002) in Palestinian refugee
camps in the West Bank. In the West Bank there are 19 of these camps
other 40 Palestinian refugee camps are scattered throughout Gaza
and Lebanon. The socioeconomic and political situations in these camps differ
from one another
column2: depending on each camp’s relation with the respective political

column1: regime and the juridical status it has granted the refugees. But despite the local
differences all of these camps seem to provide particularly illustrative cases of the
intergenerational transmission of a refugee identity and the concomitant political
narrative.
The first generation of the inhabitants of the refugee camps shares a predomi-
nantly peasant background. Originally
column2: the camps were established under the

column1: auspices of international humanitarian organizations in 1948 in order to give
shelter to the approximately 750 000 refugees that fled or were expelled during
the course of the first Arab-Israeli war
column2: which in Jewish-Israeli discourse is called

column1: the War of Independence
column2: whereas in the Arabic discourse it is referred to by the

column1: term Nakba (catastrophe in Arabic) (Sayigh 1979
However
column2: using the term “camp” already seems misleading here

column1: associated with tents. Today
column2: these camps can better be described as “concrete-

column1: structured slum neighborhoods on the peripheries of cities” (Morris 2004
which in many cases are difficult to distinguish from the neighboring cities as
they merge with their fringes. Nevertheless

2.2.1 The affirmation of intergenerational continuity
The data material presented here is the result of ethno-analytic group interviews7
conducted from 2008 to 2011 in one of the refugee camps in the West Bank
ly with members of a youth folklore and theatre group. In their shows these
youths combine political theatre with dabka
column2: an ubiquitous Arab folk dance in the

column1: Levant. The cultural center where they practice – called Markaz8 here – provides
several community services and is at the same time a meeting point for interna-
tional visitors who want to get an impression of the situation of Palestinian refu-
gees – for example by taking guided tours through the camp – or who are engag-
ing in projects of Palestine solidarity networks.

column1: Discussion
The case studies presented here both offer examples of processes of intergenera-
tional transmission of trajectory experiences in precarious places. During the
analysis of the interviews it became clear that precariousness in these cases not
only refers to economic aspects
column2: but also to the fact that the interviewees grew up

column1: in places that are defined as anomalous by their societies and by themselves. Be-
ing in these places means that “something went wrong.” Therefore
ees feel more compelled than others to deal with the question of where they come
from
sense of their family histories. With respect to the refugee camp and its dire con-
ditions of living
column2: one could assume that – in accordance with Delcroix (1999

column1: – the narrative (or myth) of struggle and return is one of the few resources par-
ents can pass on to their children. It allows them to make sense of the current sit-
uation and explain this very precariousness
column2: and it might serve to symbolize how

column1: much more parents would have liked to pass on to their children: houses
and opportunities that now lie behind the Israeli border. If their children or
grandchildren overtly turned them down by not accepting the narratives’ concomi-
tant mission
column2: it might be devastating for the elders. The aspects of this transmis-

column1: sion are two-fold: on the symbolic level it refers to their parents’ identity construc-
tions as Palestinian refugees and acknowledges their trajectory experiences of suf-
fering; on an institutional level the narrative embodies their claims to UNRWA
and to the international community
column2: which provide important services in a precar-

column1: ious situation.
In the situation of fostered children in France
crucial because of the role the institution of care plays
and because of the importance of the fostering institution in the life course. In
Emma’s case
column2: the family history that she (re-) constructed all by herself

column1: fantasies about the relation to her mother in her early childhood years appear as
biographical resources that enable her to make sense of her current situation
to develop and maintain agency. Institutional violence she had to come to terms
with during fostering led her to conceive herself as a fighter
volved her in a political struggle for gender equality. Furthermore
people who offered social support allowed her to (re-) construct herself. At first
sight
column2: the most important entity of intergenerational transmission in this case ap-

column1: pears to be the foster institution that replaces the family. However
ly by reconstructing her family narrative that Emma was enabled to gain a reflex-
ive distance from this institution and to pursue a process of further individuation.
Simultaneously
column2: she engages in a process of politicization of her own case

column1: deals with the power relations at the intersection of migration/racism and patriar-
chal oppression
column2: and defines them as the central theme of her life story.

ial transmission appears unclear and has to be reconstructed all by herself

Conclusion
Together with Howard Becker and Charles Ragin (1992) we asked ourselves
“What is this a case of?” We claim that these are cases of intergenerational trans-
mission in precarious places
column2: extreme cases in the sense that in the first the pro-

column1: cess of transmission is highly obscure and in the second it is highly explicit. The
respective younger generation’s strategies of appropriation of the content that was
passed on differ according to this level of symbolization.
However
column2: the somewhat abstract notion of “appropriation” and case structure

column1: only developed in the course of our discussion of the cases
to do this “casing” beforehand
ferring to exterior data. We at first had the impression that our cases differed a
great deal when it came to a certain “common denominator” that was yet to be
identified and theoretically conceptualized. So
question “What is a case?” we would claim that
of intergenerational transmission results from the process of research and discus-
sion itself
column2: because of the relevance of the issue for our informants. Our inform-

column1: ants implicitly outlined their respective strategies of re-interpretation to us and
made use of the interview situation to reflect upon them. Regarding the method-
ology for the research on processes of intergenerational transmission
ries and ethno-analytic group interviews are examples of very open approaches of
“data retrieval

construct her life story. The intimacy of the life story approach allows Emma to
